heading.title: PART 11 SERVICE OF DOCUMENTS OUTSIDE AUSTRALIA AND SERVICE OF EXTERNAL PROCESS [rr 11.1–11.17]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 11 SERVICE OF DOCUMENTS OUTSIDE AUSTRALIA AND SERVICE OF EXTERNAL PROCESS [rr 11.1–11.17]

p.text: [Div 3 insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 July 2006]
Subject to subrule (2), this Division applies to the service in the State of any document that is required in connection with civil proceedings pending before a court outside the State, where:
a letter of request from the court has been received by the principal registrar of the Supreme Court, and
either:
the request is for service pursuant to a convention, or
the Attorney General, or some other person authorised by the Attorney General for the purposes of this rule, certifies that effect ought to be given to the request.
[subr (1) am Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[10], effective 10 July 2009]
Division 4 of Part 11A deals with the service in New South Wales of foreign judicial documents originating in countries that are parties to the Hague Convention.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[11], effective 10 July 2009]
[r 11.13 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007 ; Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[5], effective 7 November 2008]
This Division has limited application, applying only where a request is received through official channels for service of process of a foreign court. The rules are self explanatory.

level.toc-caption: [11.13.7] Multilateral treaty for judicial assistance — Hague Convention on service abroad

heading.title: Multilateral treaty for judicial assistance — Hague Convention on service abroad

p.text: On 1Â November 2010, the Hague Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Proceedings entered into force in Australia. The procedures contemplated by this Convention are now available between Australia and the other contracting states. For information about the operation of the Convention and a list of countries that are contracting states to the Convention refer to the Hague Conference on Private International Law website at http://www.hcch.net/ and the Australian Government Attorney General’s Department website at http://www.ag.gov.au/Privateinternationallaw/Pages/Service.aspx .

Australia is also a party to numerous bilateral service Conventions. Many of these Conventions were concluded during the 1920s and 1930s. Some have been affected by subsequent changes in the composition and status of the original signatory countries (for example by the extension of independence to former territories or by either the amalgamation or the breaking up of signatory countries).
Detailed information about Australia’s bilateral treaties relating to judicial assistance is available at http://www.ag.gov.au/Privateinternationallaw/Pages/Service.aspx .

Where there is no treaty or agreement in place between Australia and a foreign country, the accepted international practice is to use diplomatic channels and rely on the concept of reciprocity: for further information see http://www.ag.gov.au/ Privateinternationallaw/Pages/Service.aspx .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.14] r 11.14 Requisite documents (cf SCR Part 57, rule 2)

p.text: In order that service may be effected in accordance with this Division, the following documents must be delivered to the principal registrar of the Supreme Court, unless the principal registrar otherwise directs:
the document to be served and 2 copies of it,
a copy of the letter of request,
if the document or letter is not in English, a translation of it in English and a copy of the translation.
[r 11.14 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007 ; Amendment 27 of 2009 Sch 1[12], effective 10 July 2009]
The principal registrar of the Supreme Court is to request the Sheriff or some other person to serve the document concerned.
The document may be served in any manner in which originating process in proceedings in the Supreme Court may be served, including substituted service pursuant to rule 10.14 .
Proceedings for an order for substituted service may be commenced only by the Attorney General.
[r 11.15 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 11.16] r 11.16 Affidavit of service (cf SCR Part 57, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit of service (cf SCR Part 57, rule 4)

p.text: After the document has been served or attempts to serve the document have failed, the Sheriff or other person requested to serve the document must make an affidavit of service, and lodge it together with such further copies of the affidavit as the principal registrar of the Supreme Court may direct.
The affidavit must state when, where and how service was effected or attempted, and the costs incurred in connection with the service or attempted service.
[r 11.16 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007]
If the request for service is made pursuant to a convention, the principal registrar of the Supreme Court must give either:
a certificate complying with subrule (2), or
such other certificate as is appropriate to the terms of the relevant convention.
A certificate referred to in subrule (1)(a):
must certify:
that the document or a copy of it was served on the person at the time, and in the manner, specified in the certificate, or
if attempts to effect service failed, that service has failed and the reasons for the failure, and
must certify the amount of the costs incurred.
If the request for service is made otherwise than pursuant to a convention, the principal registrar of the Supreme Court must give either:
a certificate complying with subrule (4), or
such other certificate as is appropriate to the terms of the letter of request.
A certificate referred to in subrule (3)(a):
must annex the letter of request, a copy of the document to be served and of any translation, and a copy of the affidavit under rule 11.16 , and
must identify the annexures, and
must certify:
that the manner of service of the document and the proof of service are such as are required by these rules in relation to the service of originating process of the Supreme Court, or
if attempts to effect service failed, that service has failed and the reasons for the failure, and
must certify the amount of the costs incurred.
In each case, the certificate is to be sealed with the seal of the Supreme Court.

The principal registrar of the Supreme Court must send the certificate to the Director-General of the Attorney General’s Department or, if the letter of request or any relevant convention so requires, to the appropriate consul or other authority.
[r 11.17 am Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 5 October 2007]
